excerpt: Cable cars access this mountain peak offering an observation deck & restaurants with sweeping views.
detail_description: Mount Rokkō, also known as Rokko-san, is a prominent attraction in Kobe, Japan. It is part of the large mountain range that includes Mt. Rokko and offers stunning views of the surrounding area. Visitors can access the peak via cable cars and enjoy an observation deck with panoramic vistas. The area is also famous for its night views, considered one of Japan's three famous night views.
name: Mount Rokkō
address: Arimacho, Kita Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-1401, Japan

excerpt: Big botanical garden with themed areas growing many flowers & herbs, plus restaurants & a gift shop.
detail_description: Kobe Nunobiki Herb Gardens is a large botanical garden located on the hill of the mountain, accessible by hiking or cable car. It offers themed areas with a variety of flowers and herbs in full bloom, along with restaurants and a gift shop. Visitors can enjoy picturesque views of Kobe from this popular spot, which also features a small museum showcasing how herbs and flowers are used to create scents.
name: Kobe Nunobiki Herb Gardens & Ropeway
address: 1 Chome-4-3 Kitanocho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0002, Japan

excerpt: Arima Onsen is an onsen, or hot springs in Kita-ku, Kobe, Japan, located near Mount Rokkō. This onsen attracts many Japanese because of its easy access from the busy cities in the Kansai metropolitan area including Osaka and Kobe. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Arima Onsen, located in Kita-ku, Kobe, Japan, is a hidden gem nestled behind Mount Rokkō. This ancient hot spring bathing resort has a history dating back over a thousand years and is known for its tranquil natural surroundings. The onsen's health-giving waters have been enjoyed by locals and visitors for centuries. The famous Kin-no-Yu (Golden Bath) and Gin-no-Yu (Silver Bath) are rich in minerals and offer therapeutic benefits.
name: Arima Onsen
address: Arimacho, Kita Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-1401, Japan

excerpt: Waterside commercial & entertainment area in an old train station with shopping, hotels & dining.
detail_description: Kobe Harborland is a vibrant waterfront commercial and entertainment district located just a short walk from Meriken Park and Kobe Station. This area was redeveloped after the 1995 earthquake and now features a mix of shopping areas, including Mosaic, South Mall, and North Mall, with department stores, boutique shops, and numerous dining options.
name: Kobe Harborland
address: 1 Chome Higashikawasakicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0044, Japan

excerpt: Established in 1868, this Chinese cultural district offers eateries, souvenir shops & mahjong clubs.
detail_description: Kobe Chinatown, also known as Nankin-machi, is a vibrant cultural district in Kobe that dates back to 1868 when Chinese merchants settled there after the port was opened for foreign trade. This area features two main streets and a central plaza filled with Chinese restaurants, street food stalls, souvenir shops, and mahjong clubs. Visitors can indulge in a variety of Chinese cuisines such as steamed buns, Szechuan noodles, dim sum, and Chinese ramen.
name: Kobe Chinatown Nankin-machi
address: 1 Chome-3-18 Sakaemachidori, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0023, Japan

excerpt: Decorative tower reaching 108m & featuring an observation deck with panoramic city views.
detail_description: Kobe Port Tower is a prominent landmark in the city, standing at 108 meters tall and offering an observation deck with stunning panoramic views of Kobe. The tower's unique design, constructed with a complex network of pipes, has made it a national symbol. Visitors can enjoy bird's-eye views of the city from its five floors during the day and witness the spectacular display of 7,040 LED lights illuminating the tower at night. It is considered a must-see attraction for anyone visiting Kobe.
name: Kobe Port Tower
address: 5-5 Hatobacho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0042, Japan

excerpt: Commemorating the devastating 1995 earthquake, this waterfront memorial displays preserved damage.
detail_description: Port of Kobe Earthquake Memorial Park is a waterfront site that serves as a tribute to the catastrophic 1995 earthquake. The Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake Memorial Museum, located within the park, offers an educational experience about the earthquake's impact on Kobe. It features a documentary showcasing the devastation and subsequent rebuilding efforts. The museum also houses displays and resources related to earthquakes and disaster prevention. The park itself provides a serene setting for reflection, with preserved damage from the earthquake on display.
name: Port of Kobe Earthquake Memorial Park
address: 2 Hatobacho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0042, Japan

excerpt: One of the world's longest suspension bridges, with tours to the top & to its exhibition center.
detail_description: The Akashi-Kaikyo Bridge is a remarkable suspension bridge that connects Kobe City and Awaji Island, spanning the scenic Akashi Strait. It holds the distinction of being one of the world's longest suspension bridges, offering tours to its exhibition center and top. Opened in 1998, it was once the longest suspension bridge globally at 3,911m.
name: Akashi-Kaikyo Bridge
address: 4 Higashimaikocho, Tarumi-ku, Kobe, Hyogo 655-0047, Japan

excerpt: Urban waterfront park featuring an observation tower, an earthquake memorial & a maritime museum.
detail_description: Meriken Park is a popular urban waterfront park in Kobe, known for its observation tower, earthquake memorial, and maritime museum. The park overlooks Kobe Port and offers a romantic evening atmosphere with impressive illumination at night. Located near Kobe Harborland, the area was redesigned after the 1995 earthquake and now features art installations and modern architecture. Visitors can enjoy the sea breeze, beautiful scenery, as well as attractions like Hotel Okura Kobe and a movie theater.
name: TIMES Meriken Park
address: 2 Hatobacho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0042, Japan

excerpt: Museum showcasing mostly contemporary Japanese & Western art, plus 19th-century European sculpture.
detail_description: Located about 4km northwest of Meriken Park in the HAT Kobe District, Hyogo Prefectural Museum of Art is a modern museum designed by renowned architect Tadao Ando. It features an extensive collection of contemporary Japanese and Western art, as well as 19th-century European sculpture.
name: Hyogo Prefectural Museum of Art
address: 1 Chome-1-1 Wakinohamakaigandori, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0073, Japan

excerpt: Kobe is a city on Osaka Bay in central Japan. It is known for its signature marbled beef and scenic setting of mountains framing the harbor. The Ikuta Shrine, dating to the 3rd century, is among Japan's oldest Shinto shrines. Antique cable cars connect Kobe to Mt. Rokko, which offers panoramic views over the port. Beyond the Mount Rokko hills are the outdoor hot springs of Arima Onsen.
detail_description: Kobe, a city in central Japan, is famous for its marbled beef and picturesque setting with mountains surrounding the harbor. It boasts historic sites like the Ikuta Shrine and offers panoramic views from Mt. Rokko accessible by antique cable cars. The city's rich history as a port includes being one of the first to open to foreign trade and hosting one of Japan's big Chinatowns.
name: Kobe
address: Hyogo, Japan

excerpt: Peaceful Japanese gardens with diverse blooms & walking paths amid waterfalls & ponds.
detail_description: Sorakuen Garden is a serene Japanese garden located just 10 minutes from Motomachi Station in Kobe. It features diverse blooms, tranquil walking paths, waterfalls, and ponds. This traditional garden was completed in the 20th century as part of the former residence of a major of Kobe and showcases nihon teien (Japanese garden) design.
name: Sorakuen Garden
address: 5 Chome-3-1 Nakayamatedori, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0004, Japan

detail_description: If you're a food enthusiast or simply enjoy indulging in exquisite cuisine, then experiencing Kobe beef should be on your travel itinerary. Renowned worldwide, Kobe beef is a type of wagyu beef known for its marbling and tenderness. It originates from purebred black Japanese cattle of the Tajima breed and must meet strict criteria to earn the label of Kobe beef. While it's associated with the city of Kobe, these cattle are actually raised in Hyogo Prefecture.
name: Kobe Beef Steak Restaurant Royal Mouriya
address: 第１岸ビル 2F, 1 Chome-9-9 Kitanagasadori, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0012, Japan

excerpt: Institution dedicated to earthquake risk management & education, featuring a memorial museum.
detail_description: The Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake Memorial Disaster Reduction and Human Renovation Institution is a museum dedicated to earthquake risk management and education. It features a memorial museum that details the 1995 Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake, which caused significant devastation in Kobe. The museum aims to educate visitors about the earthquake through immersive re-creations using projection screens, special effects, and soundscapes.
name: The Great Hanshin-Awaji Earthquake Memorial Disaster Reduction and Human Renovation Institution
address: 1 Chome-5-2 Wakinohamakaigandori, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0073, Japan

excerpt: Vibrant covered passageway between buildings offering diverse retail stores & many restaurants.
detail_description: Sannomiya Center Gai Shopping Street is a vibrant covered passageway in downtown Kobe, conveniently located near various attractions. This commercial complex houses the popular Sannomiya Centre Street underground shopping market, featuring 120 establishments offering upscale fashion, books, electronics, and eateries. Divided into three streets, it hosts a wide array of shops from well-known Japanese retailers to unique Kobe goods stores.
name: Sannomiya Center Gai Shopping Street
address: Japan, 〒650-0021 Hyogo, Kobe, Chuo Ward, Sannomiyacho, 1 Chome, ～３丁目

excerpt: Exhibits on the past, present & future of the sea, ships & local ports are featured at this museum.
detail_description: The Kobe Maritime Museum, located in the Meriken Park, is a celebration of the rich maritime history of the Port of Kobe. Established to commemorate the 120th anniversary of the port's opening, this museum offers visitors a journey through time with exhibits showcasing the past, present, and future of sea travel and local ports. The museum features ship records, diorama models, and interactive displays that provide insight into the evolution of the port from its early days to its current operations.
name: Kobe Maritime Museum
address: 2-2 Hatobacho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0042, Japan

excerpt: Mountain with an elevation of 698 meters & a scenic summit accessible by aerial tram & cable car.
detail_description: Mount Maya, with an elevation of 698 meters, is a picturesque peak accessible by aerial tram and cable car. It offers a stunning nighttime view of Kobe, which has been recognized as one of Japan's top three best night views. The Kikuseidai viewing area provides breathtaking vistas of the city lights stretching from Kobe to Osaka. This romantic and easily accessible destination in the Rokko Mountains is perfect for enjoying the beauty of nature and the glittering night scenery.
name: Mount Maya
address: Mayasan, Nada Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 657-0104, Japan

excerpt: Neoclassical buiding housing archeological artifacts, art & documents related to the city of Kobe.
detail_description: The Kobe City Museum, housed in a former 1930s bank, is a neoclassical building that showcases archaeological artifacts, art, and documents related to the city of Kobe. It opened in 1982 and features around 70,000 cultural artifacts significant to the local area. The museum's specialty is Namban art from the 16th and 17th centuries, heavily influenced by the arrival of European merchants to Japan.
name: Kobe City Museum
address: 24 Kyomachi, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 650-0034, Japan

excerpt: Sleek, contemporary structure with tool displays, building models & workshops, plus a garden.
detail_description: The Takenaka Carpentry Tools Museum, located near Shin-Kobe station, offers a captivating exploration of Japanese architecture and woodworking. Visitors can immerse themselves in the history, traditions, and artistry of traditional Japanese carpentry through sleek displays of tools, building models, and workshops. The museum showcases the unique joinery techniques that create elaborate temples and houses without nails or screws.
name: Takenaka Carpentry Tools Museum
address: 7 Chome-5-1 Kumochicho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo 651-0056, Japan

excerpt: Sannomiya is a lively retail area with department stores along Center-gai Shopping Street and around Sannomiya Station. An underground shopping area with restaurants draws commuters to sushi bars and Kobe beef eateries. Brightly lit high-rises are packed with small pubs and music clubs. Sanseido Gallery showcases modern Japanese art, while the Flower Clock, made of planted blooms, is a popular meeting spot.
detail_description: Sannomiya, located in Kobe, is a bustling retail district known for its department stores and vibrant Center-gai Shopping Street. The area around Sannomiya Station offers an underground shopping area with a variety of restaurants, including sushi bars and Kobe beef eateries. The district is also home to brightly lit high-rises housing small pubs and music clubs.
name: Sannomiya
address: 3 Chome-9 Sannomiyacho, Chuo Ward, Kobe, Hyogo, Japan
